content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the lowest fare from all eligible one-way flights for 1 adult from JFK to Heathrow on May 22, 2026.  Please interact with https://www.google.com/travel/flights/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To start searching for flights from JFK to Heathrow, I need to set the origin. The current origin is Toronto, so I need to update the "Where from?" field to "JFK."
Action: Type [13]; JFK
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The origin is now set to New York JFK. Next, I need to enter the destination, which is Heathrow, into the "Where to?" field.
Action: Type [14]; Heathrow
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The origin (JFK) and destination (Heathrow) are now correctly set. Next, the departure date needs to be set to May 22, 2026, by interacting with the "Departure" field.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current calendar is showing dates for September and October. I need to continue clicking "Next" to reach May 2026, so I can select May 22, 2026 as the departure date.
Action: Click [74]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.40
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am currently viewing October and November. To select May 22, 2026, I need to keep advancing the calendar by clicking "Next" until I reach May 2026.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.42
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays November and December. Since I need to reach May 2026, I must continue clicking "Next" to advance to the correct month and year.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.44
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows January 2026, but I need to reach May 2026. I need to continue clicking "Next" to advance to the correct month.
Action: Click [76]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.46
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now shows January and February 2026. I still need to reach May 2026, so I should keep clicking "Next" to move forward.
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.48
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays February and March 2026. I still need to advance to May 2026 to select the correct departure date, so I should continue to click "Next."
Action: Click [73]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.50
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays March and April 2026, but I need to select a date in May 2026. I should continue to click "Next" to advance the calendar.
Action: Click [75]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.52
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays May 2026. The task requires selecting May 22, 2026 as the departure date. I should click on the relevant date (label 67: "22$778") to select it.
Action: Click [67]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date is currently set to May 25, 2026, but it needs to be May 22, 2026. I need to select May 22 (label 67) on the calendar, which is now visible and not yet selected.
Action: Click [67]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The departure date is now set to Fri, May 22, 2026. To proceed and view eligible one-way flight options, I need to confirm the date selection by clicking the "Done" button at the bottom right.
Action: Click [79]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: All necessary search criteria are correctly set: the route is from New York JFK to London Heathrow, the departure date is May 22, 2026, and the passenger count is 1 adult. The next step is to initiate the flight search by clicking the "Search" button.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is visible and May 22, 2026, is correctly selected. The lowest fare for that date is shown as $778. To proceed and view specific eligible flights with prices for that date, I need to click "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: After clicking "Done," the search criteria persist, but the actual one-way flight results for the specified date (May 22, 2026) are not yet displayed. I need to click the "Search" button again to load the eligible one-way flights and display their fare details.
Action: Click [20]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.92
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar view has reappeared, showing May 22, 2026, selected with a fare of $778. However, I need to view the actual flight results for this date, which likely requires confirming the date selection again by clicking "Done."
Action: Click [81]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.94

content:
Thought: The input fields show that the search criteria are set correctly: New York JFK to London LHR, departure on May 22. However, the flight results are not displayed yet, likely because "Round trip" is still selected. To ensure only one-way flights are shown, I need to switch the trip type to "One way."
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.95
